page.title: 02 GENERAL
page.content: The Buckley-Mynydd Isa conurbation occupies hilly ground (500ft O.D.) that separates the Alun Valley to the south from the Dee estuary to the north. From the medieval period until the 20th Century man has been attracted to the district because of its resources. Coal measures were worked extensively until the heavy faulting of the area proved too expensive to work during the 1930s. Fire-resisting clays were also exploited since early times, the principal products being bricks. Pottery and clay tobacco pipes were also manufactured from the clays of glacial deposits. In modern times cheap housing has been the main attraction of the area. The county town of Mold is 2 miles away.
